contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Use Scottish English|date=May 2013}} [[Image:ScotlandGaelicSpeakers2001.gif|thumb|336px|right|Geographic Distribution of Gaelic speakers in Scotland (2001)]] The '''Gàidhealtachd''' ({{IPA-gd|kɛːəlˠ̪t̪əxk|}} {{Audio|Gaidhealtachd.ogg|listen}}, [[Scottish English|English]]: ''Gaeldom''), sometimes known as '''A' Ghàidhealtachd''' (English: ''the Gàidhealtachd''), usually refers to the Scottish [[highlands and islands]], and especially the [[Scottish Gaelic language|Gaelic]] culture of the area. The corresponding [[Irish language|Irish]] word ''[[Gaeltacht]]'' refers strictly to an Irish-speaking area. The term is also used to apply to the Gaelic-speaking areas of [[Nova Scotia]], [[Canada]]. The term ''the Gàidhealtachd'' is not truly interchangeable with the term [[Highlands of Scotland|highlands]], as it refers to the [[language]] and not to the [[geography]]. Also, many parts of the highlands no longer have substantial Gaelic-speaking populations, and some parts of what is now thought of as the Highlands have long been [[Scots language|Scots-speaking]] or English speaking areas: [[Caithness]], [[Cromarty]], [[Grantown-on-Spey]], [[Campbeltown]] etc. Conversely, several Gaelic-speaking communities lie outwith the [[Highland (council area)|Highland]], [[Argyll and Bute]] and [[Western Isles]] council areas, for example [[Isle of Arran|Arran]] and parts of [[Perth and Kinross]]. For this reason, ''the Gàidhealtachd'' also increasingly refers to the regions in [[Scotland]] where Scottish Gaelic is spoken as a [[native language]] by much of the population; it can also refer to areas of [[Nova Scotia]] and other communities in Canada, such as [[Glengarry County, Ontario]], where the language has historically been spoken. ''Galldachd'' (''Gall-dom'', ''Gall'' referring to a non-[[Gael]]) is often used for the [[Scottish Lowlands|Lowlands]], although it is also notable that the [[Hebrides]] are known as ''Innse Gall'' due to the historical presence of [[Norsemen]]. ==History== Until a few centuries ago, the Gàidhealtachd would have included much of modern-day Scotland north of the [[Firth of Forth]] and [[Galloway]] (up until the 18th century, and maybe later), excepting the [[Northern Isles]], as evidenced by the prevalence of Gaelic-derived place names throughout most of Scotland and contemporary accounts. These include [[Dundee]] from the Gaelic ''Dùn Deagh'', [[Inverness]] from ''Inbhir Nis'', [[Argyll]] from ''Earra-Ghàidheal'', [[Galloway]] from ''Gall-Ghaidhealaibh'', and possibly [[Stirling]] from ''Sruighlea'' (though the etymology is uncertain; see article). Gaelic speakers from what would be considered traditionally English-speaking/non-Gaelic regions today included [[George Buchanan (humanist)|George Buchanan]] from Stirlingshire, and [[Robert the Bruce]] and [[Margaret McMurray]] from Galloway and [[Ayrshire]]. For historical reasons, including the influence of a [[Scots language|Scots]]-speaking [[royal court]] in [[Edinburgh]] and the [[Plantation (settlement or colony)|plantation]] of [[merchant]] [[burgh]]s in much of the south and east, the Gàidhealtachd has been reduced massively to the present region of the [[Western Isles]], and the [[North-West Highlands]], [[Isle of Skye|Skye]] and [[Lochalsh]] and [[Argyll and Bute]], with small Gaelic populations existing in [[Glasgow]] and [[Edinburgh]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} The [[Highland Clearances]] of the 18th and 19th centuries also contributed to the decline of the language, as they reduced the population of the Scottish Highlands, which were predominantly Gaelic-speaking at the time. ==Canadian Gàidhealtachd== {{main|Canadian Gaelic}}[[File:Distribution-gd-CA.png|thumb|330px|right|The Gaelic speaking areas of Maritime Canada.]] Scottish Gaelic has also survived among communities descended from immigrants in parts of [[Nova Scotia]] (especially [[Cape Breton Island]]), [[Glengarry County, Ontario|Glengarry County]] in present day [[Ontario]], [[Prince Edward Island]] and [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]] (although Newfoundland had an [[Newfoundland Irish|Irish Gaelic]]-speaking population) in eastern [[Canada]] and those areas where Gaelic is spoken can also be said to be ''Gàidhealtachdan''. ==References== {{Refimprove|date=July 2008}} {{Reflist}} ==See also== *[[Scotia]] *[[Gaelic road signs in Scotland]] *[[Gaeltacht]] *[[Y Fro Gymraeg]] {{Celtic languages}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gaidhealtachd}} [[Category:Scottish culture]] [[Category:Scottish Gaelic language]]
